docs.title: Quickstart Guide
docs.text: The Systematic Trading Toolkit (STTK) is a set of open source modules that support quantitative research and the development and execution of systematic trading strategies. This Quickstart Guide will introduce you to some of the key features of the toolkit.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Before using this library in your projects, you might first want to create a sttk-testdrive directory and a dedicated virtual environment to take this library for a spin:

Step 1: Create a project directory. 

mkdir sttk-testdrive
cd sttk-testdrive

Step 2: Create a virtual environment. 

python3 -m venv ./sttk-testenv
This command will create a directory named sttk-testdrive (or any name you choose) containing the virtual environment in your local working directory: 
.
└── sttk-testenv
    ├── bin
    ├── include
    ├── lib
    └── pyvenv.cfg

Step 3: Activate the virtual environment.

MacOS/LinuxWindows 
source sttk-testenv/bin/activate

sttk-testenv\Scripts\activate

Step 4: Install the sttk library via the pip package installer: 

pip install sttk

To check your installation, run: 

pip show sttk

docs.title: Setting up Jupyter Notebook
docs.text:
It is convenient to use a Jupyter Notebook for conducting quantitative research with the Systematic Trading Toolkit. To do that, you need to install the notebook package.

Step 1: Install notebook package. 

pip install notebook

Step 2: Create a new folder for saving your Jupyter Notebook(s): 

mkdir notebooks
cd notebooks

Step 3: After having switched your current working directory to the notebooks directory, run: 

jupyter notebook --port=8888
Now, a Jupyter Notebook server will run at localhost:8888, the port number should be changed if this port is already in use.

Step 4: Open up a new Jupyter Notebook and select Python 3 (ipykernel) if asked to select a kernel.

Set the desired theme by clicking on `Settings>Theme>...` Create new Notebook by clicking on `File>New>Notebook` Select: Python 3 (ipykernel)

Step 5: Rename the Notebook file to testdrive.ipynb by clicking on Untitled in the left upper corner.

Rename Notebook file to `testdrive.ipynb`

The file structure within the sttk-testdrive directory should now look like this: 

.
├── notebooks
│   ├── .ipynb_checkpoints
│   └── testdrive.ipynb
└── sttk-testenv
    ├── bin
    ├── etc
    ├── include
    ├── lib
    ├── pyvenv.cfg
    └── share

docs.title: Download Historical Market Data
docs.text:
Step 1: Import the necessary module. 

import sttk.data.yfdownload as yfd

Step 2: Download a CSV file containing OHLC data from Yahoo Finance.

yfd.download_and_resample_yf_data(
    stock_symbol = 'AAPL',
    start_date = '2023-01-01',
    end_date = '2023-12-31',
    period = '1d',
    data_dir = '../.', #(1)!
)
  1. This guide assumes that you want to save the CSV file containing the downloaded historical market data in a subdirectory named sttk-data within your current working directory. If not, you need to specify the path in which the downloaded CSV files should be saved via the data_dir argument when calling the yfd.download_and_resample_yf_data() function.
Jupyter Notebook cell input and output

This will create a sttk-data directory inside your current working directory and save a file named AAPL_historical_2023-01-01_2023-12-31_1d.csv inside this directory. 

.
├── notebooks
│   ├── .ipynb_checkpoints
│   └── testdrive.ipynb
├── sttk-data
│   └── AAPL_historical_2023-01-01_2023-12-31_1d.csv
└── sttk-testenv
    ├── bin
    ├── etc
    ├── include
    ├── lib
    ├── pyvenv.cfg
    └── share

Step 3 (Optional): You can now inspect the downloaded CSV file with STTK's CSV inspector tool. 

import sttk.researchtools.csvinspector as csvi

csvi.csvinspector(
    csv_file_path = '.././sttk-data/AAPL_historical_2023-01-01_2023-12-31_1d.csv', 
)

Jupyter Notebook cell input and output

docs.title: Plotting a Bar Chart
docs.text:
Step 1: Import the necessary module. 

import sttk.charting.main as charting

Step 2: Plot a bar chart of the stock data obtained in the previous section (here with a dark color theme): 

charting.plot_chart(
    ".././sttk-data/ABR_historical_2023-01-01_2023-12-31_1d.csv",
    theme="dark",
    )

Plotting a Bar Chart

docs.title: Adding Indicators
docs.text:
Simple Example: Let's add a RSI sub-panel to the bottom of the bar chart. For that we first need to import the necessary module from the sttk library: 

import sttk.charting.indicators as ind


charting.plot_chart(
    ".././sttk-data/ABR_historical_2023-01-01_2023-12-31_1d.csv",
    indicators=[ind.RSI(14)],
    theme="dark",
    )
Plotting a Bar Chart with RSI sub-panel

Complex Example: Let's add a RSI sub-panel to the top of the bar chart and also add the 50-period High and Low bands (i.e. construct a Donchian Channel) to the main Bar Chart panel.

To do that, let's first create a indicator preset: 

complex_example = [
    ind.PeriodHigh(50, linewidth=0.5),
    ind.PeriodLow(50, linewidth=0.5),
    ind.RSI(14, linewidth=0.7, position="top"),
    ind.SimpleMovingAverage(50, linewidth=0.5),
]


charting.plot_chart(
    ".././sttk-data/ABR_historical_2023-01-01_2023-12-31_1d.csv",
    indicators=complex_example,
    theme="dark",
    )
Plotting a Bar Chart with RSI sub-panel and Donchian Channel upper and lower bands

docs.title: Cleaning up
docs.text:
First, close and shut down the Jupyter Notebook.

Close and shut down Jupyter Notebook

Then, shut down the Jupyter Notebook server.

Shut down Jupyter Notebook server

If desired, delete the sttk-data folder and delete the notebooks directory, ... 

cd ..
rm -r sttk-data
rm -r notebooks

... deactivate the virtual environment, and finally ... 

deactivate

... delete the whole sttk-testdrive directory: 

cd ..
rm -r sttk-testdrive

docs.title: download_and_resample_yf_data (Function)
docs.text:
download_and_resample_yf_data(
    stock_symbol: str = "AAPL",
    start_date: Optional[str] = None,
    end_date: Optional[str] = None,
    period: str = "1d",
    fallback_to_higher: bool = False,
    include_resample_base_period: bool = False,
    data_dir: Optional[str] = None
) -> None

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Downloads historical market data from Yahoo Finance, resamples it to the desired period, and saves the data to a CSV file. The function automatically handles period fallback if the requested data period is unavailable.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• stock_symbol (str, optional): The ticker symbol of the stock to download data for. Defaults to "AAPL".
  • start_date (Optional[str], optional): The start date for the data in YYYY-MM-DD format. Defaults to the start of the last full year.
  • end_date (Optional[str], optional): The end date for the data in YYYY-MM-DD format. Defaults to the end of the last full year.
  • period (str, optional): The desired resampling period (e.g., '4m' for 4 minutes, '2h' for 2 hours). Defaults to "1d".
  • fallback_to_higher (bool, optional): Whether to fall back to the next higher period if data for the requested period is unavailable. Defaults to False.
  • include_resample_base_period (bool, optional): Whether to include base period information in the filename if a fallback period is used. Defaults to False.
  • data_dir (str, optional): Directory where the 'sttk-data' folder should be created. If None, the current working directory is used.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: • None: This function does not return any value. It saves the downloaded and resampled data to a CSV file.

docs.title: Exceptions
docs.text:
• ValueError: Raised if data cannot be downloaded for the specified date range or period.
  • ModuleNotFoundError: Raised if the sttk module cannot be found when trying to determine the save directory.

docs.title: determine_download_period (Function)
docs.text: determine_download_period(period: str) -> str

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Determines the appropriate download period based on the requested period. Matches the requested period to the closest available download period supported by Yahoo Finance.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text: • period (str): The requested period (e.g., '2m', '1h', '1d').

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: • str: The appropriate download period supported by Yahoo Finance.

docs.title: Exceptions
docs.text: • ValueError: Raised if the period format is not supported.

docs.title: get_next_lower_period (Function)
docs.text: get_next_lower_period(current_period: str, fallback_to_higher: bool) -> Optional[str]

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Returns the next lower available period if the current one is deprecated or unavailable. If fallback_to_higher is True, it will return the next higher available period.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• current_period (str): The current download period that needs to be adjusted.

  • fallback_to_higher (bool): Whether to fall back to a higher period if the current one is unavailable.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: • Optional[str]: The next available period, or None if no further fallback is possible.

docs.title: resample_data (Function)
docs.text: resample_data(data: pd.DataFrame, period: str) -> pd.DataFrame

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Resamples the data to the desired period using Pandas' resample functionality.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• data (pd.DataFrame): The data to be resampled.

  • period (str): The desired resampling period (e.g., '2m', '1h', '2d').

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: • pd.DataFrame: The resampled data.

docs.title: save_to_csv (Function)
docs.text:
save_to_csv(
    data: pd.DataFrame,
    stock_symbol: str,
    start_date: str,
    end_date: str,
    original_period: str,
    download_period: str,
    include_resample_base_period: bool,
    data_dir: Optional[str]
) -> None

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Saves the resampled data to a CSV file with a descriptive filename in the sttk-data directory. If the sttk-data directory does not exist, it will be created.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• data (pd.DataFrame): The resampled data to be saved.

  • stock_symbol (str): The stock symbol (e.g., 'AAPL').

  • start_date (str): The start date for the data range.

  • end_date (str): The end date for the data range.

  • original_period (str): The originally requested period (e.g., '2d').

  • download_period (str): The period actually used to download the data (e.g., '1d').

  • include_resample_base_period (bool): Whether to include base period information in the filename if a fallback period is used.

  • data_dir (str, optional): Directory where the 'sttk-data' folder should be created. If None, the current working directory is used.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: • None: This function does not return any value. It saves the data to a CSV file.

docs.title: csvinspector (Function)
docs.text:
csvinspector(
    csv_file_path: str, 
    rows_to_display: Optional[int] = 5, 
    show_info: bool = True
) -> None

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: The csvinspector function loads a CSV file into a Pandas DataFrame, optionally displays basic DataFrame information, and displays a specified number of rows. It is compatible with both Jupyter notebooks and standard Python environments.

docs.title: Parameters
docs.text:
• csv_file_path (str): The path to the CSV file that you want to inspect.
  • rows_to_display (Optional[int], default=5): The number of rows to display from the top of the DataFrame. If None, the function displays all rows. Defaults to 5.
  • show_info (bool, default=True): A flag to determine whether to display basic DataFrame information, such as the number of rows, columns, and data types of each column. Defaults to True.

docs.title: Returns
docs.text: • None: This function does not return any value. It displays or prints the contents of the DataFrame and optionally its information.

docs.title: Exceptions
docs.text: • ValueError: Raised if the CSV file does not exist, is empty, or cannot be read as a valid CSV.

docs.title: Trunk-based Development
docs.text: Trunk-based Development is a streamlined development practice where all developers collaborate on a single branch (here: master), and commit their changes frequently. This approach promotes continuous integration, reduces the risk of complex merge conflicts, and encourages faster delivery of features.

docs.title: Step 1: Start from the master branch and pull the latest changes
docs.text:
First, ensure that you're working on the latest version of the master branch: 

git checkout master
This command switches your working directory to the master branch, which is the main branch in our trunk-based development workflow.

Next, pull the latest changes from the remote repository: 

git pull origin master
This command fetches and integrates changes from the remote master branch into your local master branch. It ensures that your local branch is up-to-date with any new commits made by other collaborators.

docs.title: Step 2: Create a new branch for your feature or bugfix
docs.text:
Now, create a new branch where you can work on your changes without affecting the master branch: 

git checkout -b feature-branch
This command creates a new branch called feature-branch and switches to it. The -b flag both creates and checks out the new branch in one step. The new branch is based on the current master branch.

docs.title: Step 3: Work on your changes, then add and commit them
docs.text:
After making the necessary changes to the code, you'll need to add and commit them: 

git add .
This command stages all the changes in your working directory (represented by the .) for the next commit. Staging files tells Git to include them in the next commit.

Next, commit the staged changes with a descriptive message: 

git commit -m "Describe the changes you made"
This command creates a new commit with the changes you've staged. The -m flag allows you to include a commit message inline, which should clearly describe the changes you’ve made.

docs.title: Step 4: Switch back to the master branch
docs.text:
After committing your changes, switch back to the master branch: 

git checkout master
This command switches your working directory back to the master branch.

docs.title: Step 5: Pull the latest changes from the remote master to ensure you're up-to-date
docs.text:
Before merging your changes, it's important to ensure that your master branch is up-to-date with the latest changes from the remote repository. 

git pull origin master
This command fetches and merges any new commits from the remote master branch into your local master branch, ensuring it reflects the most current state of the project.

docs.title: Step 6: Merge your feature branch into the master branch
docs.text:
Now, merge the changes from your feature-branch into the master branch. 

git merge feature-branch

This command merges the changes from feature-branch into the master branch. If there are any conflicts, Git will notify you, and you'll need to resolve them before completing the merge.

docs.title: Step 7: Push the updated master branch to the remote repository
docs.text:
Finally, push the updated master branch with your changes back to the remote repository: 

git push origin master
This command uploads your local master branch commits to the remote repository, making your changes available to other collaborators.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
The sttk library can be installed via the pip package installer by running: 

pip install sttk
